questions.question: 1. The property of a soil which allows it to be deformed rapidly, without rupture is ____.

explanations.a: Elastic (reversible) deformation occurs below a certain threshold and returns to the original shape when stress is removed making the deformation only temporary.
explanations.b: Plasticity is the property of a soil which allows it to be deformed rapidly, without rupture, without elastic rebound and without volume change.
explanations.c: Tenacity refers to a soil's toughness or resistance to breaking or being deformed. It is the property of the particles or molecules of the soil to resist separation.
explanations.d: One of the above answers does accurately fit the given description.

questions.question: 2. The ratio of liquid limit, minus the natural water content to the plasticity index of the soil is ____.

explanations.a: Liquid limit and plasticity index represent the state of soil that begins to behave like a liquid and as a plastic state respectively. The state between liquid limit and plastic limit represents the firmness of the soil.
explanations.b: Plasticity index (PI) is the range of water content within which the soil exhibits plastic properties; that is, it is the difference between the liquid and plastic limits.
explanations.c: The above options represent different quantities and hence both cannot be the answer simultaneously.
explanations.d: One of the above answers does accurately fit the given description.

questions.question: 3. The laboratory test results of a soil sample are given as: Percentage finer than 4.75 mm = 60%, Percentage finer than 0.075 mm = 30%, Liquid Limit = 35%, Plastic Limit = 27%. The soil classification is ____.

answers.d: ML-MI (Low Compressible Silt - Intermediate Compressible Silt)

explanations.a: It cannot be gravel (G) as less than 50% of the soil should be finer than 4.75 mm sieve for gravel but here we have 60% > 50%.
explanations.b: Plasticity Index = LL - PL = 8%. Fine grained soils are those having 50% or more pass through 75 sieve (0.075 mm). It is designated as sand (S) if 50% or more pass through 4.75 mm sieve, otherwise it is designated as gravel (G). Since the percentage finer than 4.75 mm is 60%, it is designated as sand (S). Furthermore, the percentage finer than 75 is 30% which is more than 12%. Observe the liquid limit and plasticity index on the plasticity chart. The corresponding point lies below the A- line on the plasticity chart. Hence, it is designated as M or O. Therefore, the soil is classified as SM.
explanations.c: It cannot be gravel (G) as less than 50% of the soil should be finer than 4.75 mm sieve for gravel but here we have 60% > 50%.
explanations.d: Plasticity Index = LL - PL = 8%. Fine grained soils are those having 50% or more pass through 75 sieve (0.075 mm). It is designated as sand (S) if 50% or more pass through 4.75 mm sieve, otherwise it is designated as gravel (G). Since the percentage finer than 4.75 mm is 60%, it is designated as sand (S).
